titleStmt.title: Ben Ionson, his Case is alterd. As it hath beene sundry times acted by the children of the Blacke-friers.
Case is alterd
Case is alterd.
Pleasant comedy called, The case is alterd.
titleStmt.author: Jonson, Ben, 1573?-1637.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed [by Nicholas Okes] for Bartholomew Sutton, dwelling in Paules Church-yard neere the great north doore of Paules Church,

note.p: Running title reads: A pleasant comedy, called The case is alterd.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

div.p: BEN: IONSON, HIS CASE IS ALTERD.
As it hath beene sundry times Acted by the Children of Blacke-friers.
AT LONDON Printed for Bartholomew Sutton, dwelling in Paules Church-yard neere the great north doore of S. Paules Church. 1609.

div.head: A pleasant Comedy called, the Case is Alterd.
Scaena prima.
div.stage: Sound? after a flourish: Iuniper a Cobler is discouered, sitting at worke in his shoppe and singing.

sp.speaker: Iuniper, Onion, Antony Baladino.
sp.l: YOV wofull wights giue eare a while,
And marke the tenor of my stile,
Which shall such trembling hearts vnfold
As seldome hath to fore bene told.
Such chances rare and dolefull newes
Peace a Gods name.
As may attempt your wits to muse.
A pox a God on you.
And cause such trickling teares to passe,
Except your hearts be flint or brasse:
To heare the newes which I shall tell,
That in Castella once befell.
Sbloud, where didst thou learne to corrupt a man in the midst of a verse, ha?

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Gods lid man, seruice is ready to go vp man, you must slip on your coate and come in, we lacke waiters pittyfully.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: A pittifull hearing, for now must I of a merry Cobler become mourning creature.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Well youle come.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Presto. Go to, a word to the wise, away, flie? vanish: Lye there the weedes that I disdaine to weare.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: God saue you Maister Iuniper.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: What Signior Antonio Balladino, welcome sweet Ingle,

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: And how do you sir?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Faith you see, put to my shifts here as poore retainers be oftentimes, sirrah Antony ther's one of my fellowes mightely enamored of thee, and I faith you slaue, now your come I'le bring you together, i'ts Peter Onion, the groome of the hal, do you know him.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: No not yet, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: O he is one as right of thy humour as may be, a plaine simple Rascal, a true dunce, marry he hath bene a notable vilaine in his time: he is in loue, sirrah, with a wench, & I haue preferd thee to him, thou shalt make him some prety Paradox or some Aligory, how does my coate sit? well.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I very well.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Na Gods so, fellow Iuniper, come away.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.p: Art thou there mad slaue, I come with a powder?. Sirrah fellow Onion. I must haue you peruse this Gentleman well, and doe him good offices of respect and kindnesse, as instance shall be giuen.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Nay good maister Onion what do you meane, I pray you sir you are to respectue in good faith.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: I would not you should thinke so sir, for though I haue no learning, yet I honour a scholer in any ground of the earth sir,
Shall I request your name sir?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: My name is Antonio Balladino.

sp.speaker: Oni,
sp.p: Balladino? you are not Pageant Poet to the City of Millaine sir, are you.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I supply the place sir: when a worse cannot be had sir.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I crie you mercy sir, I loue you the better for that sir, by Iesu you must pardon me, I knew you not, but Il'd pray to be better acquainted with you sir, I haue seene of your works.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I am at your seruice good Maister Onion, but concerning this maiden that you loue sir? what is she,

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p:
O did my fellow Iuniper tell you? marry sir, she is
as one may say, but a poore mans child indeede, and for mine owne part I am no Gentleman borne I must confesse, but my mind to me a kingdome is truly.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Truly a very good saying.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: T'is somewhat stale, but that's no matter.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: O t'is the better, such things euer are like bread, which the staler it is, the more holesome.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: This is but a hungry comparison in my iudgement.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Why, I'le tell you, M. Onion, I do vse as much stale stuffe, though I say it my selfe, as any man does in that kind I am sure. Did you see the last Pageant, I set forth?

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: No faith sir, but there goes a huge report on't.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Why, you shal be one of my Maecen-asses, I'le giue you one of the bookes, O you'le like it admirably.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Nay that's certaine, I'le get my fellow Iuniper to read it.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Reade it sir, I'le reade it to you.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Tut then I shall not chuse but like it.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Why looke you sir, I write so plaine, and keepe that old Decorum, that you must of necessitie like it; mary you shall haue some now (as for example, in plaies) that will haue euery day new trickes, and write you nothing but humours: indeede this pleases the Gentlemen: but the common sort they care not for't, they know not what to make on't, they looke for good matter, they, and are not edified with such toyes.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: You are in the right, I'le not giue a halfepeny to see a thousand on'hem. I was at one the last Tearme, but & euer I see a more roguish thing, I am a peece of cheese, & no onion, nothing but kings & princes in it, the foole came not out a iot.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: True sir, they would haue me make such plaies, but as I tell hem, and they'le giue me twenty pound a play, I'le not raise my vaine.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: No, it were a vaine thing, and you should sir.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Tut giue me the penny, giue me the peny, I care not for the Gentlemen I, let me haue a good ground, no matter for the pen the plot shall carry it.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p:
Indeed that's right, you are in print already for the
best plotter.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I, I might as well ha bene put in for a dumb shew too.

sp.speaker: Ont.
sp.p: I marry sir, I marle you were not, stand aside sir a while:

div.stage: Enter an armd Sewer: some halfe dozen in mourning coates following and passe by with seruice.

sp.speaker: Onion
sp.p: How now friend, what are you there? be vncouered, Would you speake with any man here?

sp.speaker: Valen,
sp.p: I, or else I must ha' returnd you no answer.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Friend, you are somewhat to peremptory, let's craue your absence: nay neuer scorne it, I am a little your better in this place.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I do acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Do you acknowledge it? nay then you shall go forth, Ile teach you how shall acknowledge it another time; go to, void, I must haue the hall purg'd, no setting vp of a rest here, packe, begone.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I pray you sir is not your name Onion?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Your friend as you may vse him, and M. Onion, say on.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: M. Onion with a murraine, come come put off this Lyons hide, your eares haue discouered you, why Peter! do not I know you Peter?

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Gods so, Valentine!

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O can you take knowledge of me now sir?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Good Lord, sirra, how thou art altred with thy trauell?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Nothing so much as thou art with thine office, but sirra, Onion is the Count Ferneze at home?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I Bully, he is aboue; and the Lord Paulo Ferneze, his son, and Maddam Aurelia, & maddam Phaenixella, his daughters, But O Valentine?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: How now man, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Faith sad, heauy, as a man of my coate ought to be.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Why man, thou wert merry inough euen now.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.l: True, but thou knowest
All creatures here soiorning, vpon this wretched earth,
Sometimes haue a fit of mourning, as well as a fit of mirth.
O Valentine, mine old Lady is dead, man.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Dead!

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I faith.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: When dyed she?

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Mary, to morrow shall be three months, she was seene going to heauen they say, about some fiue weekes agone! how now? trickling teares, ha?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Faith thou hast made me weepe with this newes.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Faith thou hast made me weepe with this newes.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Why I haue done but the parte of an Onion, you must pardon me.

div.head: Scaene. 2.
div.stage: Enter the sewer, passe by with seruice againe, the seruing-men take knowledge of Valentine as they goe. Iuniper salutes him.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: What Valentine? fellow Onion, take my dish I prithee you rogue sirrah, tell me, how thou dost, sweet Ingle.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Faith, Iuniper, the better to see thee thus frolicke.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Nay, slid I am no changling, I am Iuniper still. Exit Oni. I keepe the pristmate ha, you mad Hierogliphick, when shal we swagger.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Hierogliphick, what meanest thou by that.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Meane? Gods so, ist not a good word man? what? stand vpon meaning with your freinds. Puh, Absconde.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Why, but stay, stay, how long has this sprightly humor haunted thee?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Foe humour, a foolish naturall gift we haue in the Aequinoctiall.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Naturall, slid it may be supernaturall, this?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Valentine, I prithee ruminate thy selfe welcome. What fortuna de la Guerra.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.l: O how pittifully are these words forc't.
As though they were pumpt out on's belly.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Sirrah Ingle, I thinke thou hast seene all the strange countries in Christendome since thou wentst?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I haue seene some Iuniper.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: You haue seene Constantinople?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I, that I haue.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: And Ierusalem, and the Indies, and Goodwine sands, and the tower of Babylon, and Venice and all.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I all; no marle and he haue a nimble tong, if he practise to vault thus from one side of the world to another.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: O it's a most heauenly thing to trauel, & see countries, especially at sea, and a man had a pattent not to be sicke.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O sea sicke lest, and full of the scuruie.

div.head: Scaene 3.
div.stage: Enter Iuniper, Antonio, Sebastian, Martino, Vincentio, Balthasar and Christophero.

sp.speaker: Seba.
sp.p: Valentine? welcome I faith how dost sirra?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: How do you good Valentine.

sp.speaker: Vincen.
sp.p: Troth, Valentine, I am glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Welcome sweet rogue.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Before God he neuer lookt better in his life.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: And how ist man? what, Alla Coragio.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Neuer better gentlemen I faith.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: S'will here comes the steward.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Why how now fellowes all here? and nobody to waight aboue now they are ready to rise? looke vp one or two Signior Francesco Colomia's man how doo's your good maister.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: In health sir he will be here anon.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: Is he come home, then?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I sir he is not past sixe miles hence, he sent me before to learne if Count Ferneze were here and returne him word.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord is here; and you may tel your maister he shal come very happily to take his leaue of Lord Paulo Ferneze: who is now instantly to depart with other noble gentlemen, vpon speciall seruice.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I will tell him sir.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: I pray you doe, fellowes make him drinke.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Sirs, what seruice ist they are imployed in?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Why against the French they meane to haue a fling at Millaine againe they say.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Who leades our forces, can you tell?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Marry that do's Signior Maximilian? he is aboue, now.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Who, Maximilian of Vicenza?

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.p: I he? do you know him?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Know him? O yes he's an excellent braue soldier.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.p: I so they say, but one of the most vaine glorious men in Europe.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: He is indeed, marry exceeding valient.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: And that is rare.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.p: What.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Why to see a vaineglorious man valient.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Well he is so I assure you.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: What no further yet, come on you precious rascall, sir Valentine, Ile giue you a health I faith, for the heauens you mad Capriceio, hold hooke and line.

div.head: Scaene 4.
div.stage: Enter Lord Paulo Ferneze, his boy following him.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Sirrah go vp to Signior Angelio,
And pray him (if he can) deuise some meanes,
To leaue my father, and come speake with me.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Well heauen, be auspicious in the euent;
For I do this against my Genius,
And yet my thoughts cannot propose a reason.
Why I should feare, or faint thus in my hopes,
Of one so much endeered to my loue.
Some sparke it is, kindled within the soule:
Whose light yet breaks not to the outward sence,
That propagates this tymerous suspect;
His actions neuer carried any face
Of change, or weaknes: then I iniury him?
In being thus cold conceited of his faith,
O here he comes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How now sweet Lord, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Good faith his presence makes me halfe ashamd.
Of my straid thoughts. Boy. Bestow your selfe.
Where is my father, Signior Angelio.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Marry in the galery, where your Lordship left him.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Thats well. Then Angelio I will be briefe.
Since time forbids the vse of circumstance,
How well you are receiued in my affection,
Let it appeare by this one instance, onely
That now I will deliuer to your trust,
The deerest secrets, treasurd in my bosome,
Deare Angelio. You are not euery man,
But one, whome my election hath design'd,
As the true proper obiect of my soule:
I vrge not this t'insinuate my desert,
Or supple your tri'd temper, with soft phrases;
True frendship lothes such oyly complement:
But from th'aboundance of that loue, that flowes
Through all my spirits, is my speech enforc'd.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Before your Lordship do proceed too far,
Let me be bould to intimate thus much;
That what so ere your wisedome hath t'expose,
Be it the waightiest and most rich affaire,
That euer was included in your breast,
My faith shall poise it, if not—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: O no more,
Those words haue rapt me with their sweet effects,
So freely breath'd, and so responsible,
To that which I endeuoured to extract,
Arguing a happy mixture of our soules.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Why were there no such sympathy sweete Lord?
Yet the impressure of those ample fauours,
I haue deriu'd from your vnmatched spirit,
Would bind my faith to all obseruances.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: How! fauours Angello, ô speake not of them,
They are meere paintings, and import no merit,
Lookes my loue well? thereon my hopes are plac't:
Faith, that is bought with fauours, cannot last.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You are sought for all about the house, within,
The Count your father cals for you.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: God, what crosse euents do meet my purposes?
Now will he violently fret and grieue
That I am absent. Boy, say I come presently:
Sweet Angello, I cannot now insist
Vpon particulars, I must serue the time
The maine of all this is, I am in loue.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Why starts your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I thought I heard my father comming hither ward, list, ha?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: I heare not any thing, it was but your imagination sure.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: No, I assure your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I would worke safely.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Why, has he no knowledge of it then?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: O no, no creature yet pertakes it but your selfe
In a third person, and beleeue me friend,
The world containes not now another spirit,
To whom I would reueile it. Harke, harke,

div.stage: Seruants. Signior Paulo. Lord Ferneze. within.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: A pox vpon those brazen throated slaues,
What are they mad, trow?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Alas, blame not them,
Their seruices are (clock-like) to beset,
Backward and forward, at their Lords command,
You know my father's wayward, and his humour
Must not receiue a check, for then all obiects,
Feede both his griefe and his impatience,
And those affections in him, are like powder,
Apt to enflame with euery little sparke,
And blow vp reason, therefore Angelo, peace.

div.stage:
within. Count.
Why this is rare, is he not in the garden?
Crist.
I know not my Lord.
Count.
See, call him?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: He is comming this way, let's withdraw a little.

div.stage: within. Seruants. Signior Paulo, Lord Ferneze, Lord Paulo.

div.head: Scaene 5.
div.stage: Enter Count Ferneze, Maximilian, Aurelia, Phoenixella, Sebast. Balthasar.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: WHere should he be, trow? did you looke in the armory?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, why there? ô who would keepe such drones? Exeunt Sebast. and Baltha .How now, ha ye found him?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: No my Lord, I shall haue shortly all my family
Speake nought, but no my Lord, where is Christophero,
Looke how he stands, you sleepy knaue,
What is he not in the Garden?

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: No my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Your good Lord, ô how this smels of fennell. Enter Sebast Baltha .You haue bene in the garden it appeares, well, well.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: We cannot find him my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: He is not in the armory.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: He is not, he is no where, is he?

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Count Ferneze.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Signior.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Preserue your patience honorable Count.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Patience? a Saint would loose his patience to be crost,
As I am with a sort of motly braines,
See see, how like a nest of Rookes they stand,
Gaping on one another! now Diligence, what news bring you?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Ant please your honour.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tut, tut, leaue pleasing of my honour Diligence, you double with we, come.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: How: does he find fault with Please his Honour. S'wounds it has begun a seruing mans speech, euer since I belongd to the blew order: I know not how it may shew, now I am in blacke, but—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Whats that, you mutter sir? will you proceed?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Ant like your good Lordship.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Yet more; Gods precious.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: What, do not this like him neither?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What say you sir knaue?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Mary I say your Lordship were best to set me to schoole againe, to learne how to deliuer a message.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What do you take exceptions at me then.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Exception? I take no exceptions, but by Gods so your humours—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Go to you are a Raskall, hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Your Lordships poore seruant, I.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tempt not my patience.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Why I hope I am no spirit, am I?

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: My Lord, command your Steward to correct the slaue.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Correct him, S'bloud come you and correct him and you haue a minde to it, correct him, that's a good iest I faith, the Steward and you both, come and correct him.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nay see, away with him, pull his cloth ouer his eares.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Cloth? tell me of your cloth, here's your cloth, nay and I mourne a minute longer, I am the rottenest Onion that euer spake with a tongue.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: What call your hind's count Ferneze?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: His name is Onion Signior,

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: I thought him some such sawcy companion.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Signior Maximillian.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Sweet Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Let me intreat you, you would not regard
Any contempt flowing from such a spirit,
So rude, so barbarous.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Most noble Count vnder your fauour—

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: Why Ile tell you Signior,
Heele bandy with me word for word, nay more,
Put me to silence, strike me perfect dumb;
And so amaze me, that oftentimes I know not,
Whether to check or cherish his presumption:
Therefore good Signior.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Sweet Lord satisfie your selfe, I am not now to learn how to manage my affections, I haue obseru'd, and know the difference betweene a base wretch and a true man, I can distinguish them, the property of the wretch is, he would hurt and cannot, of the man, he can hurt, and will not.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: Go to, my merry daughter, ô these lookes,
Agree well with your habit, do they not?

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Tut, let me alone. By your fauour, this is the Gentleman I thinke, Sir you appeare to be an honorable Gentleman, I vnderstand, and could wish (for mine owne part) that things were conden't otherwise then they are: but (the world knowes) a foolish fellow, somewhat procliue, and hasty, he did it in a preiudicate humour; mary now vpon better computation, he wanes; he melts; his poore eyes are in a cold sweat. Right noble Signior, you can haue but compunction, I loue the man, tender your compassion.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Doth any man here vnderstand this fellow?

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: O God sir, I may say frustra to the comprehension of your intellection.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.l: Before the Lord, he speakes all riddle, I thinke.
I must haue a comment ere I can conceiue him.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Why he sues to haue his fellow Onion pardon'd,
And you must grant it Signior.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: O with all my soule my Lord, is that his motion?

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: I sir, and we shall retort these kinde fauours with all allacrity of spirit, we can sir, as may be most expedient, as well for the quality as the cause, till when in spight of this complement: I rest a poore Cobler, seruant to my honorable Lord here, your friend and Iuniper.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: How Iuniper?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I Signior.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: He is a sweete youth, his tongue has a happy turne when he sleepes.

div.stage: Enter Paulo Ferneze, Francisco, Colomea, Angelo, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I for then it rests, O Sir your welcome,
Why God be thanked you are found at last.
Signior Coloma truly you are welcome,
I am glad to see you sir so well returned.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I gladly thanke your honour, yet indeed
I am sory for such cause of heauinesse,
As hath possest your Lordship in my absence.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O Francisco you knew her what she was!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: She was a wise and honorable Lady.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I was she not! well weepe not she is gone,
Passons duld eye can make two grieues of one,
Whom death marke out, vertue, nor bluod can saue,
Princes, as beggers, all must feed the graue.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Are your horse ready Lord Paulo,

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I signior the stay for vs at the gate.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Well tis good. Ladies I will take my leaue of you,
Be your fortunes as your selues? faire. Come let vs to horse,
Count Ferneze I beare a spirit full of thanks for all your honorable courtesies.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sir I could wish the number and value of them more in respect of your deseruings. But Signior Maximillian. I pay you a word in priuate.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I Faith brother you are fitted for a generall yonder, Beshrow my heart (If I had Fortunatus hat here) and I would not wish my selfe a man and go with you, only t'enioy his presence.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Why do you loue him so well sister.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No by my troth, but I haue such an odde prety apprehension of his humour me thinks: that I am eene tickled with the conceite of it.
O he is a fine man.

sp.speaker: Ang
sp.p: And me thinks another may be as fine as he.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: O Angelio, do you thinke I do vrge any comparison against you? no, I am not so ill bred, as to be a deprauer of your worthines: beleeue me, if I had not some hope of your abiding with vs, I should neuer desire to go out of black whilst I liued: but learne to speake i'the nose, and turne puritan presently.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I thanke you Lady: I know you can flout.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Come doe you take it so? I faith you wrong me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I, but Maddame,
Thus to disclaime in all the effects of pleasure,
May make your sadnesse seeme to much affected,
And then the proper grace of it is lost.

sp.speaker: Phoenix
sp.l: Indeed sir, if I did put on this sadnesse
Onely abroad, and in Society,
And were in priuate merry; and quick humor'd;
Then might it seeme affected and abhord:
But as my lookes appeare, such is my spirit,
Drown'd vp with confluence of griefe, and melancholy,
That like to riuers run through all my vaines,
Quenching the pride and feruour of my bloud.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: My honorable Lord? no more.
There is the honour of my bloud ingag'd,
For your sonnes safety.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Signior, blame me not,
For tending his security so much,
He is mine onely sonne, and that word onely,
Hath with his strong, and reprecussiue sound,
Stroke my heart cold, and giuen it a deepe wound.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Why but stay, I beseech you, had your Lordship euer any more sonnes then this.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why haue not you knowen it Maximilian?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Let my Sword faile me then.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I had one other yonger borne then this,
By twise so many howers as would fill
The circle of a yeare, his name Camillo,
Whome in that blacke, and fearfull night I lost,
(Tis now a nineteene yeares agone at least,
And yet the memory of it fits as fresh
Within my braine as twere but yesterday)
It was that night wherein the great Chamont,
The generall for France surprised Vicenza,
Me thinks the horrour of that clamorous shout
His souldiers gaue when they attaind the wall,
Yet tingles in mine eare, me thinkes I see
With what amazed lookes, distracted thoughts,
And minds confus'd, we, that were citizens,
Confronted one another: euery street
Was fild with bitter selfe tormenting cries,
And happy was that foote, that first could presse,
The flowry champaigne, bordering on Verona
Heere I (imploy'd about my deare wiues safety)
Whose soule is now in peace) lost my Camillo.
Who sure was murdered by the barbarous Souldiers,
Or else I should haue heard— my heart is great.
Sorrow is faint? and passion makes me sweat.

sp.speaker: Max
sp.p: Grieue not sweet Count: comfort your spirts, you haue a sonne a noble gentleman, he stands in the face of honour: For his safety let that be no question. I am maister of my fortune, and he shall share with me. Farewell my honorable Lord. Ladies once more adiew, for your selfe maddam you are a most rare creature, I tell you so, be not proud of it, I loue you: come Lord Paulo to horse.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Adiew good Signior Francesco: farewell sister.

div.stage: Sound a tucket, and as they passe euery one seuerally depart, Maximilian, Paulo Ferneze and Angelo remaine

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How shall we rid him hence.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Why well inough? sweet Signior Maximilian.
I haue some small occasion to stay:
If it may please you but take horse afore
Ile ouer take you, ere your troopes be ranged.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Your motion hath tast wel: Lord Ferneze I go

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Now if my loue faire Rachel, were so happy,
But to looke forth. See fortune doth me grace.
Before I can demaund? how now loue.
Where is your father?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Gone abroad my Lord:

sp.speaker: Pau:
sp.p: Thats well,

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: I but I feare heele presently returne,
Are you now going my most honored Lord?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I my sweet Rachel.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Before God, she is a sweet wench.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Rachel I hope I shall not need to vrge,
The sacred purity of our effects,
As if it hung in triall or suspence:
Since in our hearts, and by our mutuall vowes,
It is confirmd and seald in sight of heauen.
Nay doe not weepe, why starte you? feare not, Loue.
Your father cannot be returned so soone,
I prithee doe not looke so heauily
Thou shalt want nothing

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: No is your presence nothing,
I shall want that, and wanting that, want all
For that is all to me.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Content thee sweet
I haue Made choise here of a constant friend
This gentleman? one, whose zealous loue
I doe repose more, then on all the world,
Thy beauteous selfe excepted: and to him,
Haue I committed my deere care of thee,
As to my genius, or my other soule.
Receiue hi gentle loue and what deffects,
My absence proues, his presence shall supply.
The time is enuious of our longer stay.
Farewell deere Rachel.

sp.speaker: Rach:
sp.l: Most deere Lord, adew,
Heauen and honour crowne your deeds, and you,

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Faith tell me Angelio how dost thou like her?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Troth well my Lord, but shall I speake my mind.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I prithee doe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: She is deriud too meanely to be wife
To such a noble person, in my iudgement.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Nay then thy iudgement is to meene, I see:
Didst thou neare read in difference of good
Tis more to shine in vertue then in bloud.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come you are so sententious my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Here comes her father. How dost thou good Iaques?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: God saue thee Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: What should this meane? Rachel open the dore.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Sbloud how the poore slaue lookes, as though
He had bene haunted by the spirit Lar,
Or seene the ghost of some great Satrapas.
In an vnsauory sheet.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: I muse he spake no, belike he was amazd
Comming so suddenly and vnprepard? Well lets go:

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.l: SO now inough my heart, beat now no more;
At least for this afright, what a could sweat,
Flow'd on my browes, and ouer all my bosome!
Had I not reason? to behold my dore
Beset with vnthrifts, and my selfe abroad?
Why Iaques? was their nothing in the house
Worth a continuall eye, a vigelent thought,
Whose head should neuer nod, nor eyes once wincke?
Looke on my coate; my thoughts; worne quite thred bare,
That time could neuer couer with a nappe,
And by it learne, neuer with nappes of sleepe,
To smother your conceipts of that you keepe.
But yet, I maruell, why these gallant youths
Spoke me so faire, and I esteemd a beggar?
The end of flattery, is gaine, or lechery:
If they seeke gaine of me, they thinke me rich,
But that they do not: for their other obiect:
Tis in my handsome daughter, if it be.
And by your leaue, her handsomnesse may tell them
My beggery counterfeits, and, that her neatnesse,
Flowes from some store of wealth, that breakes my coffers,
With this same engine, loue to mine owne breed.
But this is answered: Beggers will keepe fine,
Their daughters, being faire, though themselues pine.
Well then, it is for her, I, t'is sure for her,
And I make her so briske for some of them,
That I might liue alone once with my gold.
O t'is a sweet companion! kind and true,
A man may trust it when his father cheats him;
Brother, or friend, or wife, ô wondrous pelfe,
"That which makes all men false, is true it selfe.
But now this maid, is but suppos'd my daughter:
For I being Steward to a Lord of France,
Of great estate, and wealth, called Lord Chammount,
He gone into the warres, I stole his treasure,
(But heare not, any thing) I stole his treasure,
And this his daughter, being but two yeares old,
Because it lou'd me so, that it would leaue
The nurse her selfe, to come into mine armes,
And had I left it, it would sure haue dyed.
Now herein I was kinde, and had a conscience;
And since her Lady mother that did dye
In child-bed of her, loued me passing well,
It may be nature fashiond this affection,
Both in the child and her: but hees ill bred,
That ransackes tombes, and doth deface the dead.
I'le therefore say no more: suppose the rest,
Here haue I chang'd my forme, my name and hers.
And liue obsurely, to enioy more safe
My deerest treasure. But I must abroad, Rachel.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: What is your pleasure sir?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Rachel I must abroad.
Lock thy selfe in, but yet take out the key,
That whosoeuer peepes in at the key-hole,
May yet imagine there is none at home.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: But harke thee Rachel: say a theefe should come,
And misse the key, he would resoule indeede
None were at home, and so breake in the rather:
Ope the doore Rachel, set it open daughter;
But sit in it thy selfe: and talke alowd,
As if there were some more in house with thee:
Put out the fire, kill the chimnies hart,
That it may breath no more then a dead man,
The more we spare my child, the more we gaine.

sp.speaker: CHrist.
sp.p: What sayes my fellow Onion? come on.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: All of a house sir, but no fellowes, you are my Lords Steward, but I pray you what thinke you of loue, sir?

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Of loue Onion? Why it's a very honourable humor.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Nay if it be but worshipfull I care not.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Go to, it's honorable, checke not at the conceit of the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.l: But in truth sir, you shall do well to think well of loue:
For it thinkes well of you, in me, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Gramercy fellow Onion: I do thinke well, thou art in loue, art thou?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Partly sir, but I am asham'd to say wholy.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Well, I will further it in thee to any honest woman, or maiden, the best I can.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.l: Why now you come neere him sir, he doth vaile,
He doth remunerate, he doth chaw the cud in the kindnesse
Of an honest imperfection to your worship.

sp.speaker: Chris
sp.p: But who is it thou louest fellow Onion?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Mary a poore mans daughter, but none of the honestest, I hope.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Why, wouldst thou not haue her honest?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O no, for then I am sure she would not haue me. T'is Rachel de Prie.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Why, she hath the name of a very vertuous mayden.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: So shee is sir, but the fellow talkes in quiddits, he.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: What wouldst thou haue me do in the matter?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Do nothing sir, I pray you, but speake for me.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: In what maner?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: My fellow Iuniper can tell you sir.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Why as thus sir. Your worship may commend him for a fellow fit for consanguinity, and that he shaketh with defire of procreation, or so.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: That were not so good, me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: No sir, why so sir? what if you should say to her, correborate thy selfe sweete soule, let me distinguish thy pappes with my fingers, diuine Mumps, prety Pastorella? lookest thou so sweet and bounteous? comfort my friend here.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Well I perceiue you wish, I should say something may do him grace, and further his desires, and that be sure I will.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I thanke you sir, God saue your life, I pray God sir.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Your worship is too good to liue long: youle contaminate me no seruice.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Command thou wouldest say, no good Iuniper.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Health and wealth sir.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: This wench will solicite for my selfe,
Making my Lord and maister priuy to it;
And if he second me with his consent,
I will proceede, as hauing long ere this,
Though her a worthy choyce to make my wife.

sp.speaker: AVre.
sp.l: Roome for a case of matrons coloured blacke,
How motherly my mothers death hath made vs?
I would I had some girles now to bring vp;
O I could make a wench so vertuous,
She should say grace to euery bit of meate,
And gape no wider then a wafers thicknesse:
And she should make French cursies, so most low,
That euery touch should turne her ouer backward.

sp.speaker: Phoeni.
sp.l: Sister, these words become not your attire,
Nor your estate: our vertuous mothers death
Should print more deepe effects of sorrow in vs,
Then may be worne out in so little time.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Sister, faith you take too much Tobacco,
It makes you blacke within, as y'are without.
What true-stich sister? both your sides alike?
Be of a sleighter worke: for of my word,
You shall be sold as deere or rather deerer?
Will you be bound to customes and to rites?
Shed profitable teares, weepe for aduantage;
Or else, do all things, as you are enclynd.
Hate when your stomacke serues (saith the Physitian)
Not at eleuen and sixe. So if your humour
Be now affected with this heauinesse.
Giue me the reines and spare not, as I do,
In this my pleasurable appetite,
It is Praecisianisme to alter that
With austere iudgement, that is giuen by nature.
I wept you saw too, when my mother dyed:
For then I found it easier to do so,
And fitter with my moode, then not to weepe.
But now tis otherwise, another time
Perhaps I shall haue such deepe thoughts of her,
That I shall weepe a fresh, some twelue month hence,
And I will weepe, if I be so dispos'd,
And put on blacke, as grimly then, as now;
Let the minde go still with the bodies stature,
Iudgement is fit for Iudges, giue me nature.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: See Signior Angelo here are the Ladies,
Go you and comfort one, Ile to the other.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Therefore I come sir, I'le to the eldest.
God saue you Ladies, these sad moodes of yours,
That make you choose these solitary walkes,
Are hurtfull for your beauties.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: If we had them.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Come, that condition might be for your hearts,
When you protest faith, since we cannot see them.
But this same heart of beauty, your sweet face
Is in mine eye still.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: O you cut my heart with your sharpe eye.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Nay Lady thats not so, your heart's to hard.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: My beauties hart?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: O no.
I meane that regent of affection, Maddam,
That tramples on al loue with such contempt in this faire breast.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: No more, your drift is sauour'd,
I had rather seeme hard hearted

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Then hard fauour'd,
Is that your meaning, Lady?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Go too sir.
Your wits are fresh I know, they need no spur,

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And therefore you wil ride them.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Say I doe.
They will not tire I hope?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No not with you, hark you sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Tis much pitty Maddam.
You should haue any reason to retaine
This signe of griefe, much lesse the thing disignde.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Griefes are more fit for Ladies then their pleasures.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: That is for such as follow nought but pleasures.
But you that temper them so wel with vertues,
Vsing your griefes so it would prooue them pleasures.
And you would seeme in cause of griefes & pleasures equally pleasant.

sp.speaker: Phoe
sp.l: Sir so I do now.
It is the excesse of either that I striue
So much to shun in all my proou'd endeauours,
Although perhaps vnto a generall eye,
I may appeare most wedded to my griefes,
Yet doth my mind forsake no tast of pleasure,
I meane that happy pleasure of the soule,
Deuine and sacred contemplation
Of that eternall, and most glorious blisse.
Proposed as the crowne vnto our soules.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I will be silent, yet that I may serue
But as a Decade in the art of memory
To put you stil in mind of your owne vertues
When your too serious thoughts make you too sad)
Accept me for your seruant honored Lady.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Those cerimonies are too comon signior Francis,
For your vncommon grauitie, and iudgement,
And fits them onely, that are nought but cerimony.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Come, I will not sue, stally to be your seruant,
But a new tearme, will you be my refuge?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Your refuge, why sir.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: That I might fly to you, when all else faile me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And you be good at flying, be my Plouer.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay take away the P.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Tut, then you cannot fly.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Ile warrant you. Ile borrow Cupids wings.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Masse then I feare me youle do strange things:
I pray you blame me not, if I suspect you,
Your owne confession simply doth detect you,
Nay and you be so great in Cupids bookes,
T'will make me Iealous. you can with your lookes
(I warrant you) enflame a womans heart,
And at your pleasure take loues golden dart,
And wound the brest of any vertous maide.
Would I were hence: good Faith I am affraid,
You can constraine one ere they be aware,
To run mad for your loue?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: O this is rate.

sp.speaker: COunt.
sp.l: Close with my daughters gentlemen? wel done,
Tis like your selues: nay lusty Angelo,
Let not my presence make you bauke your sport,
I will not breake a minute of discourse
Twixt you and one of your faire Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: One of my mistresses? why thinks your Lordship I haue so many

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Many? no Angelo.
I do not thinke th'ast many, some fourteene
I here thou hast, euen of our worthiest dames,
Of any note, in Millaine:

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay good my Lord fourteene: it is not so.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: By'th the Masse that ist, here are their names to shew
Fourteene, or fifteene t'one. Good Angelo.
You need not be ashamd of any of them,
They are gallants all.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Sbloud you are such a Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Nay stay sweet Angelo, I am disposed
A little to be pleasant past my coustome,
He's gone? he's gone, I haue disgrast him shrewdly,
Daughters take heede of him, he's a wild youth,
Looke what he sayes to you beleeue him not,
He will sweare loue to euery one he sees.
Francisco, giue them councell, good Francisco,
I dare trust thee with both, but him with neither.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Your Lordship yet may trust both them with him.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Well goe your waies away; how now Christopher,
What newes with you?

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: I haue an humble suit to your good Lordship.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: A suit Christopher? what suit I prithee?

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.l: I would craue pardon at your Lordships hands,
If it seeme vaine or simple in your sight.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Ile pardon all simplicity, Christopher,
What is thy suit?

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.l: Perhaps being now so old a batcheler,
I shall seeme halfe vnwise, to bend my selfe
In strict affection to a poore yong maide.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What? is it touching loue Christopher?
Art thou dispost to marry, why tis well.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.l: I, but your Lordship may imagine now
That I being steward of your honours house.
If I be maried once, will more regard
The maintenance of my wife and of my charge,
Then the due discharge of my place and office.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No, no, Christopher, I know thee honest.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: Good faith my Lord, your honour may suspect it— but—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Then I should wrong thee, thou hast euer been
Honest and true, and will be still I knowe.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: I but this marriage alters many men:
And you may feare, it will do me my Lord,
But ere it do so? I will vndergoe
Ten thousand seuerall deaths.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I know it man.
Who wouldst thou haue I prithee?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: Rachel de prie,
If your good Lordship, graunt me your consent.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Rachel de prie? what the poore beggers daughter?
Shees a right handsome maide, how poore soeuer,
And thou hast my consent, with all my hart.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I humbly thanke your honour. Ile now aske her father.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Do so Christofero thou shalt do well.
Tis strange (she being so poore) he should affect her,
But this is more strange that my selfe should loue her.
I spide her, lately, at her fathers doore,
And if I did not see in her sweet face
Gentry and noblenesse, nere trust me more:
But this perswasion, fancie wrought in me,
That fancie being created with her lookes,
For where loue is he thinke his basest obiect
Gentle and noble: I am farre in loue,
And shall be forc'd to wrong my honest steward,
For I must sue, and seeke her for my selfe;
How much my duetie to my late dead wife,
And my owne deere renowne so ere it swaies,
He to her father straight. Loue hates delays.

div.head: Scaene 8.
div.stage: Enter Onion, Iuniper, Valentine, Sebastian, Balthasar, Martino.

sp.speaker: Onion.
sp.p: Come on Ifaith, lets to some exercise or other my hearts: Fetch the hilts fellow Iuniper, wilt thou play:

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.p: I cannot resolue you? tis as I am fitted with the ingenuity, quantity, or quality of the cudgell.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: How dost thou bastinado the poore cudgell with tearmes?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: O Ingle, I haue the phrases man, and the Anagrams and the Epitaphs, fitting the mistery of the noble science.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Ile be hangd & he were not misbegotten of some fencer.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Sirrah Valentine, you can resolue me now, haue they their maisters of defence in other countries as we haue here in Italy?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O Lord, I, especially they in Vtopia, there they performe their prizes and chalenges, with as great cerimony as the Italian or any nation else.

sp.speaker: Balt
sp.p: Indeed? how is the manner of it (for gods loue) good Valentine?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Ingle? I prithee make recourse vnto vs, wee are thy friends and familiars: sweet Ingle.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Why thus sir.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: God a mercy good Valentine, nay go on.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Silentium bonus socius Onionus, good fellow Onion be not so ingenious, and turbulent: so fir? and how? how sweete Ingle?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Marry, first they are brought to the publicke Theater:

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: What? ha? they Theater there

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Theaters? I and plaies to: both tragidy and comedy & set foorth with as much state as can be imagined?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: By Gods so; a man is nobody, till he has trauelled.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: And how are their plaies? as ours are? extemporall?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O no? all premeditated things, and some of them very good I faith, my maister vsed to visite them often when he was there.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Why how are they in a place where any man may see them?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I, in the common Theaters, I tell you. But the sport is at a new play to obserue the sway and variety of oppinion that passeth it. A man shall haue such a confus'd mixture of iudgement, powr'd out in the throng there, as ridiculous, as laughter it selfe: one saies he likes not the writing, another likes not the plot, another not the playing. And sometimes a fellow that comes not there past once in fiue yeare at a Parliament time or so, will be as deepe myr'd in censuring as the best, and sweare by Gods foote he would neuer stirre his foote to see a hundred such as that is.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I must trauell to see these things, I shall nere think well of my selfe else.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Fellow Onion, Ile beare thy charges and thou wilt but pilgrimize it along with me, to the land of Vtopia.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Why but me thinkes such rookes as these should be asham'd to iudge.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Not a whit? the rankest stinkard of them all, will take vpon him as peremptory, as if he had writ himselfe in artibus magister.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: And do they stand to a popular censure for any thing they present.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I euer, euer, and the people generally are very acceptiue and apt to applaud any meritable worke, but there are two sorts of persons that most commonly are infectious to a whole auditory.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: What be they?

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: I come lets know them.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: It were good they were noted.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p:
Marry? one is the rude barbarous crue, a people that haue no braines, and yet grounded iudgements, these will hisse
any thing that mounts aboue their grounded capacities. But the other are worth the obseruation, I faith.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: What be they? what be they?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Faith a few Caprichious gallants.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Caprichious? stay, that word's for me.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: And they haue taken such a habit of dislike in all things, that they will approue nothing, be it neuer so conceited or elaborate, but sit disperst, making faces, and spitting, wagging their vpright eares and cry filthy, filthy. Simply vttering their owne condition, and vsing their wryed countenances in stead of a vice, to turne the good aspects of all that shall sit neere them, from what they behold.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.l: O that's well sayd, lay them downe, come sirs.
Who plaies, fellow Iuniper, Sebastian, Balthasar:
Some body take them vp, come.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Ingle Valentine?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Not I sir, I professe it not.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Sebastian.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Balthasar.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Who? I?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Come, but one bout, Ile giue hem thee, I faith.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: Why, heres Martino.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Foe he, alas he cannot play a whit, man.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: That's all one: no more could you in stata quo prius, Martino, play with him, euery man has his beginning and conduction.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Will you not hurt me fellow Onion?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Hurt thee, no? and I do, put me among pot-hearbs, And chop me to peeces, come on?

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: By your fauor sweet bullies giue them roome, back, so, Martino, do not looke so thin vpon the matter.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Ha, well plaid, fall ouer to my legge now? so, to your guard againe, excellent, to my head now, make home your blow: spare not me, make it home, good, good a gaine.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Why how now Peter?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Gods so, Onion has caught a bruise.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Couragio? be not caprichious? what?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Caprichious? not I, I scorn to be caprichious for a scrach, Martino must haue another bout, come.

sp.speaker: Val. Seb. Balth.
sp.p: No, no, play no more, play no more.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Foe, tis nothing a philip, a deuise, fellow Iuniper prithee get me a Plantan, I had rather play with one that had skil by halfe.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: By my troth, fellow Onion, twas against my will.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.l: Nay that's not so, twas against my head,
But come, weele ha one bout more.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Not a bout, not a stroke.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: No more, no more.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Why Ile giue you demonstration, how it came, Thou openest the dagger to falsifie ouer with the back sword frick, and he interrupted, before he could fall to the close.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: No, no, I know best how it was better than any man here, I felt his play presently: for looke you, I gathered vpon him thus, thus do you see? for the double locke, and tooke it single on the head.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: He sayes very true, he tooke it single on the head.

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Come lets go.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Here fellow Onion, heres a cob-web.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: How? a cob-web Martino, I will haue another bout with you? S'wounds do you first breake my head, and then giue me a plaister in scorne? come to it, I will haue a bout.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: God's my witnesse.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Tut! your witnesse cannot serue.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: S'bloud? why what, thou art not lunatike, art thou? and thou bee'st auoide Mephostophiles. Say the signe shoud be in Aries now: as it may be for all vs, where were your life? Answere me that?

sp.speaker: Sebast.
sp.p: Hee sayes well, Onion.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I indeed doo's he.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p:
Come, come, you are a foolish Naturalist, go, get a white a of an egge, and a little flax, and close the breach of the
head, it is the most conducible thing that can be. Martino, do not insinuate vpon your good fortune, but play an honest part and beare away the bucklers.

sp.speaker: ANge.
sp.l: My yong and simple friend, Paulo Ferneze,
Bound me with mighty solemne coniurations,
To be true to him, in his loue, to Rachel,
And to solicite his remembrance still,
In his enforced absence, much, I faith.
True to my friend in cases of affection?
In womens cases? what a iest it is?
How silly he is, that imagines it!
He is an asse that will keepe promise stricktly
In any thing that checkes his priuate pleasure;
Chiefly in loue. S'bloud am not I a man?
Haue I not eyes that are as free to looke?
And bloud to be enflam'd as well as his?
And when it is so, shall I not pursue
Mine owne loues longings, but preferre my friends?
I tis a good foole, do so, hang me then,
Because I swore, alas, who doo's not know,
That louers periuries are ridiculous?
Haue at thee Rachel: Ile go court her sure:
For now I know her father is abroad.
S'bloud see, he is here, ô what damn'd lucke is this?
This labour's lost, I must by no meanes see him.

sp.speaker: IAq.
sp.l: Mischiefe and hell, what is this man a spirit,
Haunts he my houses ghost? still at my doore?
He has beene at my doore, he has beene in,
In my deere doore: pray God my gold be safe.
Gods pitty, heres another. Rachel, ho Rachel.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: God saue you honest father.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Rachel, Gods light, come to me, Rachel, Rachel!

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: Now in Gods name what ayles he? this is strange!
He loues his daughter so, Ile lay my life,
That hee's afraid, hauing beene now abroad,
I come to seeke her loue vnlawfully.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Tis safe, tis safe, they haue not rob'd my treasure.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Let it not seeme offensiue to you sir.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Sir, Gods my life, sir, sir, call me sir.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Good father here me.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: You are most welcome sir,
I meant almost; and would your worship speake?
Would you abase your selfe to speake to me?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: Tis no abasing father: my intent
Is to do further honour to you sir
Then onely speake: which is to be your sonne.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: My gold is in his nostrels, he has smelt it,
Breake breast, breake heart, fall on the earth my entrailes,
With this same bursting admiration!
He knowes my gold, he knowes of all my treasure,
How do you know sir? whereby do you guesse?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: At what sir? what ist you meane?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I aske, an't please your Gentle worship, how you know?
I meane, how I should make your worship know
That I haue nothing—
To giue with my poore daughter? I haue nothing:
The very aire, bounteous to euery man,
Is scant to me, sir.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I do thinke good father, you are but poore,

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: He thinkes so, harke, but thinke so:
He thinkes not so, he knowes of all my treasure.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: Poore man he is so ouerioyed to heare
His daughter may be past his hopes bestowed,
That betwixt feare and hope (if I meane simply)
He is thus passionate.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Yet all is safe within, is none without?
No body breake my walles?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: What say you father, shall I haue your daughter?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I haue no dowry to bestow vpon her.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I do expect none, father.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: That is well,
Then I beseech your worship make no question
Of that you wish, tis too much fauour to me.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: Ile leaue him now to giue his passions breath,
Which being setled, I will fetch his daughter:
I shall but moue too much, to speake now to him.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: So, hee's gone, would all were dead and gone,
That I might liue with my deere gold alone.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Here is the poore old man.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Out of my soule another, comes he hither?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Be not dismaid old man, I come to cheere you.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: To me by heauen,
Turne ribs to brasse, turne voice into a trumpet,
To rattle out the battels of my thoughts,
One comes to hold me talke, while th'other robbes me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: He has forgot me sure: what should this meane?
He feares authority, and my want of wife
Will take his daughter from him to defame her:
He that hath naught on earth but one poore daughter,
May take this extasie of care to keepe her.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: And yet tis safe: they meane not to vse force,
But fawning comming. I shall easly know
By his next question, if he thinke me rich,
Whom see I? my good Lord?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Stand vp good father, I call thee not father for thy age,
But that I gladly wish to be thy sonne,
In honoured marriage with thy beauteous daughter.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: O, so, so, so, so, so, this is for gold,
Now it is sure, this is my daughters neatnesse,
Makes them beleeue me rich. No, my good Lord,
Ile tell you all; how my poore haplesse daughter
Got that attire she weares from top to toe.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why father, this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O yes, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Indeed it is not.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Nay sweet Lord pardon me? do not dissemble,
Heare your poore beads-man speake; tis requisite
That I (so huge a beggar) make account
Of things that passe my calling: she was borne
T'enioy nothing vnderneath the sonne:
But that, if she had more then other beggars
She should be enuied: I will tell you then
How she had all she weares, her warme shooes (God wot)
A kind maide gaue her, seeing her go barefoot
In a cold frosty morning; God requite her;
Her homely stockings

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Father, Ile heare no more, thou mou'st too much
With thy too curious answere for thy daughter,
That doth deserue a thousand times as much,
Ile be thy Sonne in law, and she shall weare
Th'attire of Countesses.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: O good my Lord,
Mock not the poore, remembers not your Lordship,
That pouerty is the precious gift of God.
As well as riches, tread vpon me, rather
Then mocke my poorenes.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Rise I say:
When I mocke poorenes, then heauens make me poore.

sp.speaker: NVn.
sp.l: See heres the Count Ferneze, I will tell him
The haplesse accident of his braue sonne,
That hee may seeke the sooner to redeeme him,
God saue your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You are right welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: I would I brought such newes as might deserue it.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What, bring you me ill newes?

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Tis ill my Lord,
Yet such as vsuall chance of warre affoords,
And for which all men are prepar'd that vse it,
And those that vse it not, but in their friends,
Or in their children.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Ill newes of my sonne?
My deere and onely sonne, Ile lay my soule,
Ay me accurs'd, thought of his death doth wound me,
And the report of it will kill me quite.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: Tis not so ill my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Hee's taken prisoner, and that's all.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: That's enough, enough,
I set my thoughts on loue, on seruile loue,
Forget my vertuous wife, feele not the dangers,
The bands and wounds of mine owne flesh and bloud,
And therein am a mad man: therein plagu'd,
With the most iust affliction vnder heauen.
Is Maximilian taken prisoner to?

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: My good my Lord, he is return'd with prisoners.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Ist possible, can Maximilian?
Returne, and view my face without my sonne,
For whom he swore such care as for himselfe?

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.p: My Lord no care can change the euents of war.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O! in what tempests do my fortunes saile,
Still wrackt with winds more foule and contrary,
Then any northen guest, or Southerne flawe?
That euer yet inforc't the sea to gape,
And swallow the poore Marchants traffique vp?
First in Vicenza, lost I my first sonne;
Next here in Millaine my most deere lou'd Lady:
And now my Paulo, prisoner to the French,
Which last being printed with my other griefes,
Doth make so huge a volume, that my brest
Cannot containe them. But this is my loue:
I must make loue to Rachel, heauen hath throwne,
This vengeance on me most deseruedly:
Were it for nought but wronging of my steward.

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: My Lord since onely mony may redresse
The worst of this misfortune, be not griued,
Prepare his ransome and your noble sonne
Shall greete your cheered eyes, with the more honour.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I will prepare his ransome: gratious heauen
Grant his imprisonment may be his worst,
Honored and souldier-like imprisonment,
And that he be not manacled and made
A drudge to his proude foe. And here I vow,
Neuer to dreame of seeme-les amorous toyes,
Nor aime at other ioy on earth,
But the fruition of my onely sonne.

div.head: Scaene 5.
div.stage: Enter Iaques with his gold and a scuttle full of horse-dung.

sp.speaker: Iaq,
sp.l: He's gone: I knew it; this is our hot louer,
I will beleeue them! I! they may come in
Like simple woers, and be arrant theeues,
And I not know them! tis not to be told,
What seruile villanies, men will do for gold,
O it began to haue a huge strong smell,
Which lying so long together in a place;
Ile giue it vent, it shall ha shift inough,
And if the diuell, that enuies all goodnesse,
Haue told them of my gold, and where I kept it,
Ile set his burning nose once more a worke,
To smell where I remou'd it, here it is:
Ile hide and couer it with this horse-dung:
Who will suppose that such a precious nest
Is crownd with such a dunghill excrement?
In my deere life, sleepe sweetly my deere child.
"Scarce lawfully begotten, but yet gotten,
" And that's enough. Rot all hands that come neere thee
Except mine owne. Burne out all eyes that see thee,
Except mine owne. All thoughts of thee be poyson
To their enamor'd harts, except mine owne,
Ile take no leaue, sweet Prince great Emperour,
But see thee euery minute, King of Kings,
Ile not be rude to thee, and turne my backe,
In going from thee, but go backward out:
With my face toward thee, with humble curtesies,
None is within. None ouerlookes my wall.
To haue gold, and to haue it safe, is all.

div.head: Scaene 1.
div.stage: Enter Maximilian, with souldiers Chamount, Camilla, Ferneze, Pacue.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Lord Chamount and your valient friend there, I cannot say welcome to Millaine: your thoughts and that word are not musicall, but I can say you are come to Millaine.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Mort diew.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Gar soone.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Gentlemen (I would cal an Emperour so) you are now my prisoners, I am sorry, marry this, spit in the face of your fortunes, for your vsage shall be honorable.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Wee know it signior Maximilian,
The fame of al your actions sounds nought else,
But perfect honour from her swelling cheeks.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: It shall do so still I assure you, and I will giue you reason, there is in this last action (you know) a noble gentleman of our party, & a right valient; semblably prisoner to your general, as your honor'd selfe's to me, for whose safety, this tongue hath giuen warrant to his honorable father, the Count Ferneze. You conceiue me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I signior.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Well? then I must tell you your ransomes be to redeeme him, what thinke you? your answer.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Marry with my Lords leaue here I say signior,
This free & ample offer you haue made,
Agrees well with your honour, but not ours:
For I thinke not but Chamount is aswell borne
As is Ferneze, then if I mistake not,
He scornes to haue his worth so vnderprised,
That it should neede an adiunct, in exchange,
Of any equall fortune, Noble Signior?
I am a souldier, and I loue Chamount,
Ere I would bruse his estimation,
With the least ruine of mine owne respect,
In this vild kind, these legs should rot with irons,
This body pine in prison, till the flesh
Dropt from my bones in flakes, like withered leaues,
In heart of Autumne, from a stubborne Oke.

sp.speaker: Maxi.
sp.p: Mounsieur Gasper (I take it so is your name) misprise me not, I wil trample on the hart, on the soule of him that shall say, I will wrong you: what I purpose, you cannot now know; but you shall know, and doubt not to your contentment. Lord Chamount, I will leaue you, whilest I go in and present my selfe to the honorable Count, till my regression so please you, your noble feete may measure this priuate, pleasant and most princely walke, Souldiers regard them and respect them.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: O Ver bon: excellenta gull, he tak'a my Lord Chamount for Mounsieur Gaspra, & Mounsieur Gaspra for my Lord Chamont, ô dis be braue for make a me laugh'a, ha, ha, ha, ô my heart tickla.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I but your Lordship knowes not what hard fate
Might haue pursued vs, therefore howsoere
The changing of our names was necessary
And we must now be carefull to maintaine
This error strongly, which our owne deuise,
Hath thrust into their ignorant conceits,
For should we (on the taste of this good fortune)
Appeare our selues, t'would both create in them
A kinde of iealousie, and perchaunce inuert
Those honourable courses they intend.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: True my deere Gasper: but this hang by here,
Will (at one time or other) on my soule
Discouer vs: A secret in his mouth
Is like a wild bird put into a cage,
Whose doore no sooner opens, but tis out.
But sirra, if I may but know
Thou vtterst it

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Vtteria? vat Mounsieur?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: That he is Gasper, and I true Chamont.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: O pardone moy, fore my tongue shall put out de secreta,
Shall breede de cankra in my mouth.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Speake not so loud Pacue.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Foe, you shall not heare foole, for all your long eare, Reguard Mounsieur: you be de Chamont, Chamont be Gaspra.

div.stage: Enter Count Ferueze, Maximilian, Francesco, Aurelia, Phoenixella, Finio.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Peace, here comes Maximilian.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: O belike that's the Count Ferneze, that old man.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Are those his daughters, trow?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I sure, I thinke they are.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Fore God the taller is a gallant Lady.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: So are they both beleeue me.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: True my honorable Lord, that Chamont was the father of this man.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O that may be, for when I lost my sonne,
This was but yong it seemes.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Faith had Camillo liued,
He had beene much about his yeares, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: He had indeed, well, speake no more of him.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Signior perceiue you the errour? twas no good office in vs to stretch the remembrance of so deere a losse. Count Ferneze, let sommer sit in your eye, looke cheerefully sweete Count, will you do me the honour to confine this noble spirit within the circle of your armes?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Honor'd Chamont reach me your valiant hand,
I could haue wisht some happier accident
Had made the way vnto this mutuall knowledge,
Which either of vs now must take of other,
But sure it is the pleasure of our fates,
That we should thus be wrack't on Fortunes wheele,
Let vs prepare with steeled patience
To tread on torment, and with mindes confirm'd
Welcome the worst of enuy.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Noble Lord, tis thus. I haue here (in mine honour) set this gentleman free, without ransome, he is now himselfe, his valour hath deseru'd it, in the eye of my iudgement. Mounsieur Gasper you are deere to me: fortuna non mutuat genus. But to the maine, if it may square with your Lordships liking, and his loue, I could desire that he were now instantly imployed to your noble Generall in the exchange of Ferneze for your selfe, it is the businesse that requires the tender hand of a friend.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I, and it would be with more speed effected,
If he would vndertake it.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: True my Lord. Mounsieur Gasper, how stand you affected to this motion?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My duty must attend his Lordships will.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: What sayes the Lord Chamont?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: My will doth then apprroue what these haue vrg'd.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Why there is good harmony, good musicke in thise Mounsieur Gasper, you shall protract no time, onely I will giue you a bowle of rich wine to the health of your Generall, another to the successe of your iourney, and a third to the loue of my sword. Passe.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Aurelia and Phoenixella.

sp.speaker: Anre.
sp.l: Why how now sister in a motley muse?
Go to, thers somewhat in the wind, I see.
Faith this browne study suites not with your blacke,
Your habit and your thoughts are of two colours.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Good faith me thinkes that this young Lord Chamont fauours my mother, sister, does he not?

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: A motherly conceite, ô blind excuse,
Blinder then loue himselfe. Well sister, well.
Cupid hath tane his stand in both your eyes, The case is alterd.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: And what of that?

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Nay nothing but a Saint.
Another Bridget, one that for a face
Would put downe Vesta, in whose lookes doth swim,
The very sweetest creame of modesty.
You to turne tippet? fie, fie, will you giue
A packing penny to Virginity.
I thought youl'd dwell so long in Cypres Ile,
You'd worship Maddam Venus at the length;
But come, the strongest fall, and why not you?
Nay, do not frowne.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Go. go, you foole. Adiew.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Well I may iest, or so: but Cupid knowes
My taking is as bad, or worse then hers.
O Mounsieur Gasper? if thou bee'st a man,
Be not affraid to court me, do but speake,
Challenge thy right and weare it: for I sweare
Till thou arriud'st, nere came affection here.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.l: Come on my sweet finicall Pacue, the very prime
Of Pages, heres an excellent place for vs to practise in,
No body fees vs here, come lets to it.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Contenta: Reguarde, vou le Preimer.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Sirra Finio?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Mort deiu le pesant.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Didst thou see Valentine?

sp.speaker: Finio.
sp.p: Valentine? no.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Fini.
sp.p: No. Sirrah Onion, whither goest?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O I am vext, he that would trust any of these lying trauellers.

sp.speaker: Finio.
sp.p: I prithee stay good Onion.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Mounsieur Onion, vene ca, come hidera, Ie vou prey. By gar me ha see two, tree, foure hundra towsand of your Cousan hang. Lend me your hand, shall prey for know you bettra.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I thanke you good signior Parla vou? O that I were in an other world, in the Ingies, or some where, that I might haue roome to laugh.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: A we fort boon: stand? you be deere now, me come, Boon iour Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: God morrow good signior.

sp.speaker: Pac
sp.p: By gar, be mush glad for see you.

sp.speaker: Fin
sp.p: I returne you most kind thanks sir.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: How? how? Sbloud this is rare?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Nay, shall make you say rare by and by, Reguard Mounsieur Finio,

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Signior Pache.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Dieu vou gard Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: God saue you sweet signior

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Mounsieur Onion? is not fort boon.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Beane? quoth he, would I were in debt of a pottle of beanes I could do as much.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Welcome signior, whats next?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: O here, Void de grand admiration, as should meet perchance Mounsieur Finio,

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Mounsieur Pacue

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Iesu? by Gar who thinke wee shall meete here?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: By this hand I am not a little proud of it, sir

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: This trick is onely forthe the chamber, it cannot be cleanly done abroad,

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Well what say you for dis den? Mounsieur:

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Nay pray, sir.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Par ma foy vou bein encounters?

sp.speaker: Fin
sp.p: What doe you meane sir, let your gloue alone.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Comen, se porte la sante.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Faith exceeding well sir.

sp.speaker: Pac,
sp.p: Trot, be mush ioy for heire.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: And how ist with you sweet signior Pache.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Fat comme vou voyer.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Yong gentlemen? spirits of bloud, if euer youle tast of a sweet peece of mutton, do Onion a good turne now.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Que que, parla Mounseir, what ist.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Faith teach me one of these tricks.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: O me shall doe presently, stand you deere, you signior deere, my selfe is here: so fort bein, now I parle to Mounseir Onion, Onion pratla to you, you speaka to me, so, and as you parle chang the bonet, Mounseir Onion.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Mounseiur Finio.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Mounseur Pacue.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Pray be couera.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Nay I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: What do you meane.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Pardon moy, shall be so,

sp.speaker: Oni
sp.p: O God sir.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Not I in good faith sir.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: By gar you must.

sp.speaker: Oni:
sp.p: It shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Nay then you wrong me,

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Well and euer I come to be great.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: You be big enough for de Onion already,

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I meane a great man.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Then thou'dst be a monster.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Well God knowes not what fortune may doe, commaund me, vse me from the soule to the crowne, and the crowne to the soule: meaning not onely from the crowne of the head, and the sole of the foot, but also the foote of the mind and the crownes of the purse, I cannot stay now yong gentlemen but— time was, time is, and time shall be.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Sweet Iasper I am sorry we must part,
But strong necessity enforceth it.
Let not the time seeme long vnto my friend,
Till my returne for by our loue I sweare
(The sacred spheare wherein our soules are knit)
I will endeauour to effect this busines
With all industrious care and happy speed.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My Lord these circumstances would come well,
To one lesse capable of your desert
Then I: in whom your mirrit is confirmed
With such authenticall and grounded proues.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Well I will vse no more. Gasper adiew.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Farewell my honored Lord.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Commend me to the Lady, my good Gasper.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I had remembred that had not you vrgd it.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Once more adiew sweet Gasper.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: My good Lord.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Thy vertues are more precious then thy name,
Kind gentleman I would not sell thy loue,
For all the earthly obiects that mine eyes,
Haue euer tasted, sure thou art nobly borne,
How euer fortune hath obscurd thy birth:
For natiue honour sparkles in thine eyes,
How may I blesse the time wherein Chamont
My honored father did surprise vicenza,
Where this my friend (knowen by no name) was found,
Being then a child and scarce of power to speake,
To whom my father gaue this name of Gasper,
And as his owne respected him to death,
Since when wee two haue shard our mutuall fortunes,
With equall spirits, and but deathes rude hand,
No violence shall dissolue this sacred band.

div.stage: Enter Iuniper in his shop singing: to him Onion.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Fellow Iuniper, no more of thy songs and sonets, sweet Iuniper, no more of thy hymnes and madrigals, thou sing'st, but I sigh.

sp.speaker: Iuni
sp.p: Whats the matter Peter ha? what in an Academy still, still in sable, and costly black array? ha?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Prithee rise mount, mount sweet Iuniper, for I goe downe the wind, and yet I puffe: for I am vext.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p:
Ha Bully? vext? what intoxicate? is thy braine in a
quintescence? an Idea? a metamorphosis? an Apology? ha rogue? come this loue feeds vpon thee, I see by thy cheekes, and drinkes healthes of vermilion, teares I see by thine eyes.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I confesse Cupids carouse, he plaies super negulum with my liquor of life

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Tut, thou art a goose to be Cupids gull, go to, no more of this contemplations, & calculations, mourne not, for Rachels thine owne

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: For that let the higher powers worke: but sweet Iuniper, I am not sad for her, and yet for her in a second person, or if not so yet in a third.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: How second person? away, away, in the crotchets already Longitude and Latitude? what second? what person? ha?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Iuniper, Ile bewray my selfe before thee, for thy company is sweet vnto me, but I must entreat thy helping hand in the case.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Tut? no more of this surquedry; I am thine owne? ad vngem vpsie freeze: pell mell, come, what case? what case?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: For the case it may be any mans case, aswell as mine, Rachel I meane, but Ile medle with her anon, in the meane time, Valentine is the man hath wrongd me.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: How my Ingle wrong thee, ist possible?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Your Ingle, hang him infidell, well and if I be not reuengd one him let Peter Onion (by the infernall Gods) be turned to al eeke or a scalion, I spake to him for a ditty for this handkerchier.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Why, has he not done it?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Done it, not a verse by this hand.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: O in dichus illis, O preposterous, wel come be blith, the best iudge of them al is somtimes dul, fellow Onion pardon mine Iugle: he is a man, has imperfections and declinations, as other men haue, his masse somtimes cannot carnet nor prognisticat and come of, as it should, no matter, Ile hammer our a paraphrase for thee my selfe.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p:
No sweet Iuniper, no danger doth breed delay, loue
makes me chollericke I can beare no longer.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Not beare? what my mad Meridian slaue? not be are? what?

sp.speaker: Oni.
