sp.p: Cupids burden: tis to heauy, to tollerable, and as for the handkerchire and the posie: I will not trouble thee: but if thou wilt goe with me into her fathers backside, old Iaques backside, and speake for me to Rachel, I wil not being ratitude, the old man is abroad and all.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Art thou sure on't.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: As sure as an obligation.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Lets away then, come we spend time in a vaine circumference, trade I cashire thee til to morrow, fellow Onion for thy sake I finish this workiday.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: God a mercy, and for thy sake Ile at any time make a holiday.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay I prithee Rachel, I come to comfort thee, Be not so sad.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: O signior Angelo,
No comfort but his presence can remoue,
This sadnesse from my heart.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nay then y'are fond,
And want that strength of iudgement and election,
That should be attendent on your yeares and forme,
Will you, because your Lord is taken prisoner,
Blubber and weepe and keepe a peeuish stirre,
As though you would turne turtle with the newes,
Come, come, be wise. Sblood say your Lord should die:
And you goe marre your face as you begin,
What would you doe trow? who would care for you;
But this it is, when nature will bestow
Her gifts on such as know not how to vse them,
You shall haue some that had they but one quarter
Of your faire beauty? they would make it shew
A little otherwise then you do this,
Or they would see the painter twice an hower,
And I commend them I, that can vse art,
With such iudiciall practise.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: You talke iedly,
If this be your best comfort keepe it still,
My sences cannot feede on such sower cates.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And why sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Nay leaue good signior.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come I haue sweeter vyands yet in store.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: I in any case mistres Rachel.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Rachel?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Gods pitty signior Angelo, I here my father, away for Gods sake.

sp.speaker: Ang:
sp.p: S'bloud, I am betwixt, I thinke, this is twice now, I haue been serued thus.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Pray God he meet him not.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O braue? she's yonder, O terrible shee's gone.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Yea? so nimble in your Dilemma's, and your Hiperbole's Hay my loue? O my loue, at the first sight: By the masse.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O how she skudded, O sweet scud, how she tripped, O delicate trip and goe.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Come thou art enamored with the influence of her profundity, but sirrah harke a little.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O rare, what? what? passing Ifaith, what ist? what ist?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: What wilt thou say now, if Rachel stand now, and play hity tity through the key hole, to behold the equipage of thy person:

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O sweet equipage, try good Iuniper, tickle her, talke, talke, O? rare

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Mistris Rachel (watch then if her father come) Rachel? Madona? Rachel? No.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Say I am here, Onion or Peter or so.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: No, Ile knock, weele not stand vpon Horizons, and tricks, but fall roundly to the matter.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Well said sweet Iuniper: Horizons? hang hem? knock, knock.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Whose there? father.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Father no? and yet a father, if you please to be a mother.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Well said Iuniper, to her againe, a smack or two more of the mother

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Do you here? sweet soule, sweet radamant? sweet mathauell one word Melpomine? are you at leasure.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: At leasure? what to doe?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: To doe what, to doe nothing, but to be liable to the extasie of true loues exigent, or so, you smell my meaning.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Smell, filthy, fellow Iuniper filthy? smell? O most odious.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: How filthy.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Filthy, by this finger? smell? smell a rat, smel a pudding, away these tricks are for truls, a plaine wench loues plaine dealing, ile vpon my selfe, smel to march paine wench.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: With all my heart, Ile be legitimate and silent as an apple-squire, Ile see nothing, and say nothing.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Sweet hart, sweet hart?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: And bag pudding, ha, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: What Rachel my girle what Rachel;

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Gods lid?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: What Rachel,

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Here I am

sp.speaker: Oni
sp.p: What rakehell cals Rachel: O treason to my loue.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Its her father on my life, how shall wee entrench and edifie our selues from him?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O conni-catching Cupid.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: How in my back side? where? what come they for?
sp.stage: Onion gets vp into a tree.
sp.l: Where are they? Rachel? theeues, theeues?
Stay villaine slaue: Rachel? vntye my dog.
Nay theife thou canst not scape.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: I pray you sir.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: A pitifull Onion, that thou hadst a rope.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Why Rachel: when I say: let loose my dog? garlique my mastiue, let him loose I say.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: For Gods sake here me speake, keepe vp your cur.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I feare not garlique, heele not bite Onion his kinsman pray God he come out, and then theile not smell me.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: well then deliuer, come deliuer slaue?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: What should I deliuer?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O thou wouldst haue me tell thee? wouldst thou shew me thy hands, what hast thou in thy hands?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Here be my hands.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Stay are not thy fingers ends begrimd with durt, no thou hast wipt them.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Wipt them?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I thou villaine? thou art a subtile knaue, put off thy shewes, come I will see them, giue me a knife here Rachel, Ile rip the soles.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: No matter he's a cobler, he can mend them.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: What are you mad? are you detestable, would you make an Anatomy of me, thinke you I am not true Ortographie?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Ortographie, Anatomy?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: For Gods sake be not so inuiolable, I am no ambuscado, what predicament call you this, why do you intimate so much.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I can feele nothing.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Bir Lady but Onion feeles something.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Soft sir, you are not yet gon, shake your legs, come, and your armes, be briefe, stay let me see these drums, these kilderkins, these bombard slops, what is it crams hem so.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Nothing but haire.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Thats true, I had almost forgot this rug, this hedghogs nest, this hay mowe, this beares skin, this heath, this firsbush.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p:
O let me goe, you teare my haire, you reluolue my
braines and vnderstanding.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Heart, thou art somewhat eas'd? halfe of my feare
Hath tane his leaue of my, the other halfe
Still keepes possession in dispight of hope,
Vntill these amorous eyes, court my faire gold:
Deare I come to thee: friend, why art not gone?
Auoid my soules vexation, Sathan hence?
Why doest thou stare on me, why doest thou stay?
Why por'st thou on the ground with theeuish eyes?
What see'st thou there, thou curre? what gap'st thou at?
Hence from my house, Rachel, send garlick forth.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: I am gone sir, I am gone, for Gods sake stay.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Pack, and thanke God thou scap'st so well away.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: If I scape this tree, destinies, I defie you.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I cannot see by any Characters
Writ on this earth, that any fellon foote
Hath tane acquaintance of this hallowed ground.
None sees me: knees do homage to your Lord.
Tis safe, tis safe, it lyes and sleepes so soundly,
Twould do one good to looke on't. If this blisse
Be giuen to any man that hath much gold,
Iustly to say tis safe, I say tis safe.
O what a heauenly round these two words dance
Within me and without me: First I thinke hem,
And then I speake hem, then I watch their sound,
And drinke it greedily with both mine eares,
Then thinke, then speake, then drinke their sound againe,
And racket round about this bodies court.
These two sweet words: tis safe: stay I will feed
My other sences, ô how sweet it smels

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I mar'le he smels not Onion, being so neere it.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Downe to thy graue againe, thou beauteous Ghost,
Angels men say, are spirits: Spirits be
Inuisible, bright angels are you so?
Be you inuisible to euery eye.
Saue onely these: Sleepe, Ile not breake your rest,
Though you breake mine: Deare Saints adiew, adiew:
My feete part from you, but my soule dwels with you.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.l: Is he gone? ô Fortune my friend, & not fortune my foe,
I come downe to embrace thee, and kisse thy great toe.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Fellow Onion? Peter.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Fellow Iuniper. What's the old panurgo gone? departed, cosmografied, ha?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O I, and harke Sirrah. Shall I tell him? no.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Nay, be briefe and declare, stand not vpon conodrums now, thou knowest what contagious speeches I haue sufferd for thy sake and he should come againe and inuent me here.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.l: He saies true, it was for my sake, I will tell him.
Sirra Iuniper? and yet I will not.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: What sayest thou sweete Onion?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: And thou hadst smelt the sent of me when I was in the tree, thou wouldest not haue said so: but Sirra, The case is alterd with me, my heart has giuen loue a box of the eare, made him kicke vp the heeles I faith.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Sayest thou me so, wad Greeke? how haps it? how chances it.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: I cannot hold it, Iuniper, haue an eye, looke, haue an eye to the doore, the old prouerb's true, I see: gold is but mucke. Nay Gods so Iuniper to the doore, an eye to the maine chance, here you slaue, haue an eye.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: O inexorable! ô infallible! ô infricate deuine, and superficiall fortune.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Nay, it will be sufficient anon, here, looke heere.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: O insolent good lucke! How didst thou produce th'intelligence of the gold' mynerals.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.l: Ile tell you that anon, heere, make shift, conuey, cramme.
Ile teach you how you shall call for garlike againe I faith.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: S'bloud what shall we do with all this? we shall nere bring it to a consumption.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Consumption? why weele bee most sumptuously attir'd, man.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: By this gold, I will haue three or foure most stigmaticall suites presently.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Ile go in my foot-cloth, Ile turne Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: So will I.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: But what badge shall we giue, what cullison?

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: As for that lets vse the infidelity and commiseration of some harrot of armes, he shall giue vs a gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: A gudgeon? a scutheon thou wouldst say, man.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: A scutcheon or a gudgeon, all is one.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Well, our armes be good inough, lets looke to our legges.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Content, weele be iogging.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Rachel? we retire: garlike God boy ye.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: Farewell sweete Iaques.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Farewell sweete Rachel, sweet dogge adiew.

div.stage: Enter Maximilian, Count Ferneze, Aurelia, Phoenixella, Pache.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Nay but sweet Count.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Away, Ile heare no more,
Neuer was man so palpably abusd,
My sonne so basely marted; and my selfe
Am made the subiect of your mirth and scorne.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Count Ferneze you tread to hard vpon my patience,
Do not persist I aduise your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I will persist, and vnto thee I speake.
Thou, Maximilian thou hast iniur'd me.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Before the Lord:

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Sweet signior.

sp.speaker: Phoe
sp.p: O my father.

sp.speaker: Mvx.
sp.p: Lady let your father thank your beauty.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.l: By gar me shall be hang for tella dis same,
Metella madamoyselle, she tell her sadera.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: The true Chamount set free, and one left here
Of no descent, clad barely in his name.
Sirrah boy come hither, and be sure, you speake the simple truth:

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: O pardone moy mounsieur,

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Come leaue your pardons, and directly say.
What villaine is the same that hath vsurpt,
The honor'd name and person of Chamount:

sp.speaker: Pac
sp.p: O Mounsieur, no point villaine, braue Cheualier, Mounsieur Gasper.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Mounsieur Gasper, on what occasion did they change their names, what was their policy, or their pretext.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Me canno tell, par ma foy Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: My honorable Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tut tut, be silent.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Silent? Count Ferneze, I tell thee if Amurath the great
Turke were here I would speake, and he should here me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: So will not I.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: By my fathers hand, but thou shalt Count, I say till this instant, I was neuer toucht in my reputation: here me you shall knowe that you haue wrongd me, and I will make you acknowledge it, if I cannot my sword shall.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: By heauen I will not, I will stop mine eares,
My sences loath the Sauiour of thy breath.
Tis poyson to me, I say I will not heare.
What shall I know, tis you haue iniurd me,
What will you make? make me acknowledge it.
Fetch forth that Gasper, that lewd counterfeit.
Ile make him to your face approue your wrongs.
Come on false substance, shadow to Chamont:
Had you none else to worke vpon but me,
Was I your fittest proiect? well confesse,
What you intended by this secret plot.
And by whose policy it was contriu'd,
Speake truth, and be intreated courteously,
But double with me, and resolue to proue
The extremest rigor that I can inflict.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My honor'd Lord, heare me with patience,
Nor hope of fauour, not the feare of torment,
Shall sway my tongue, from vttring of a truth.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tis well, proceed then.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The morne before this battell did begin,
Wherein my Lord Chamount and I were tane,
We vow'd one mutuall fortune, good or bad,
That day should be imbraced of vs both,
And vrging that might worst succeede our vow,
We there concluded to exchange our names.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Then Maximilian tooke you for Chamount.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: True noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Tis false, ignoble wretch,
Twas but a complot to betray my sonne.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Count, thou lyest in thy bosome, Count:

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Lye?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nay I beseech you honor'd gentlemen,
Let not the vntimely ruine of your loue,
Follow these sleight occurents; be assured
Chamounts returne will heale these wounds againe,
And breake the points of your too piercing thoughts.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Returne? I when? when will Chamount returne?
Heele come to fetch you, will he? I tis like,
Youl'd haue me thinke so, that's your policy.
No, no, yong gallant, your deuice is stale,
You cannot feed me with so vaine a hope.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My Lord, I feede you not with a vaine hope,
I know assuredly he will returne,
And bring your noble sonne along with him.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: I, I dare pawne my soule he will returne.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O impudent dirision? open scorne?
Intollerable wrong? is't not inough?
That you haue plaid vpon me all this while;
But still to mocke me, still to iest at me?
Fellowes, away with him, thou ill-bred slaue,
That sets no difference twixt a noble spirit,
And thy owne slauish humour, do not thinke
But ile take worthy vengeance on thee, wretch?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Alas, these threats are idle, like the wind,
And breed no terror in a guiltlesse mind.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nay, thou shalt want no torture, so resolue, bring him away.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Welcome the worst, I suffer for a friend,
Your tortures will, my loue shall neuer end.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Alas poore gentleman, my fathers rage
Is too extreame, too sterne and violent
O that I knew with all my strongest powers,
How to remoue it from thy patient breast,
But that I cannot, yet my willing heart,
Shall minister in spight of tyranny
To thy misfortune, something there is in him,
That doth enforce this strange affection,
With more then common rapture in my breast:
For being but Gasper, he is still as deare
To me, as when he did Chamount appeare.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: But in good sadnesse Signior, do you thinke Chamount will returne?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Do I see your face, Lady?

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: I sure, if loue haue not blinded you.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: That is a question, but I will assure you no, I can see, and yet loue is in mine eye: well, the Count your father simply hath dishonor'd me: and this steele shall engraue it on his burgonet.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: Nay, sweet Signior.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Lady, I do preferre my reputation to my life,
But you shall rule me, come lets march.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Ile follow Signior, ô sweet Queene of loue!
Soueraigne of all my thoughts, and thou faire fortune,
Who (more to honour my affections)
Hast thus translated Gasper to Chamount.
Let both your flames now burne in one bright speare;
And giue true light to my aspiring hopes,
Hasten Chamounts returne, let him affect me,
Though father, friends, and all the world reiect me.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Sigh for a woman, would I fould mine armes,
Raue in my sleepe, talke idly being awake,
Pine and looke pale, make loue-walkes in the night,
To steale cold comfort from a day-starres eyes.
Kit, thou art a foole, wilt thou be wise? then lad
Renounce this boy-gods nice idolatry,
Stand not on complement, and wooing trickes,
Thou louest old Iaques daughter, doest thou?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Loue her?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Come, come, I know't, be rul'd and shees thine owne,
thou't say her father Iaques, the old begger,
Hath pawnd his word to thee, that none but thou,
Shalt be his sonne in law.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: He has.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: He has? wilt thou beleeue him, and be made a kooke,
To waite on such an antique wether cocke;
Why he is more inconstant then the sea,
His thoughts, Cameleon-like, change euery minute:
No Kit, worke soundly, steale the wench away,
Wed her, and bed her, and when that is done,
Then say to Iaques, shall I be your sonne?
But come to our deuise, where is this gold?

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Heere Signior Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Bestow it, bid thy hands shed golden drops,
Let these bald french crownes be vncouered,
In open sight, to do obeysance
To Iaques staring eyes when he steps forth,
The needy beggar will be glad of gold.
So, now keepe thou aloose, and as he treades
This guilded path, stretch out his ambling hopes,
With scattring more & more, & as thou go'st, cry Iaques, Iaques

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Tust, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: First ile play the ghost, Ile cal him out, Kit keep aloofe.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: But Signior Angelo. Where wil your selfe and Rachel stay for me, after the iest is ended?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Masse, that's true, at the old Priory behinde S. Foyes.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Agreed, no better place, ile meete you there.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Do good foole, do, but ile not meet you there.
Now to this geere, Iaques, Iaques, what Iaques?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Who cals? whos's there?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Who cals?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Steward, he comes, he comes Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: What voice is this? no body here, was I not cald? I was.
And one cride Iaques with a hollow voyce,
I was deceiu'd, no I was not deceiu'd,
See see, it was an Angell cald me forth,
Gold, gold, man-making gold, another starre,
Drop they from heauen, no, no, my house I hope
Is haunted with a Fairy. My deere Lar,
My houshold God, My Fairy on my knees.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: My Lar doth call me, ô sweet voyce.
Musicall as the spheares, see, see, more gold.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Iaques.
What Rachel, Rachel, lock my doore, looke to my house.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Shut fast my doore, a golden crowne, Iaques shall be a king.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: To a fooles paradice that path will bring
Thee and thy houshold Lar.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: What means my father, I wonder what strange humor.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Come sweete soule, leaue wondring, start not, twas I laid this plot to get thy father forth.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: O Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: O me no oo's, but heare, my Lord your loue,
Paulo Ferneze is returnd from warre,
Lingers at Pont Valeria, and from thence
By post at midnight last, I was coniur'd
To man you thither, stand not on replies,
A horse is sadled for you, will you go,
And I am for you, if you will stay, why so.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: O Angelo, each minute is a day till my Ferneze come, come weele away sir.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Sweet soule I guesse thy meaning by thy lookes,
At pont Valerio thou thy loue shalt see,
But not Ferneze, Steward fare you well.
You wait for Rachel to, when can you tell?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: O in what golden circle haue I dan'st?
Millaine these od'rous and enfloured fields
Are none of thine, no heres Elizium,
Heere blessed ghosts do walke, this is the Court
And glorious palace where the God of gold
Shines like the sonne, of sparkling maiesty;
O faire fethered, my red-brested birds,
Come flye with me, ile bring you to a quier,
Whose consort being sweetned with your sound:
The musique will be fuller, and each hower
These eares shall banquet with your harmony ô, ô, ô,

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: At the old priorie, behind Saint Foyes,
That was the place of our appointment sure:
I hope he will not make me loose my gold,
And mock me to, perhaps they are within: Ile knock.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O God, the case is alterd.

sp.speaker: Christ.
sp.p: Rachel?

sp.speaker: Angelo?
sp.p: Signior Angelo?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Angels? I where? mine Angels? wher's my gold?
Why Rachel? O thou theeuish Canibal,
Thou eatest my flesh in stealing of my gold.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: What gold?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: What gold? Rachel call help, come forth,
Ile rip thine entrailes, but ile haue my gold:
Rachel why comes thou not? I am vndone,
Ay me she speakes not, thou hast slaine my child.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: What is the man possest trow? this is strange,
Rachel I see is gone with Angelo:
Well ile once againe vnto the priory,
And see if I can meete them.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Tis too true,
Th'ast made away my child, how hast my gold:
O what Hienna cald me out of dores,
The theife is gone: my gold's gone, Rachels gone,
Al's gone? saue I that spend my cries in vaine,
But ile hence too, and die or end this paine.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.l: Swonds, let me goe, hay catso, catch him aliue,
I call, I call, boy, I come, I come sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Page hold my rapier, while I hold my freind here.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O heer's a sweet metamorphosis, a cupple of buzzards turn'd to a paire of peacocks.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Signior Onion, lend me thy boy to vnhang my rapier. On. Signior Iuniper for once or so, but troth is, you must inueigle, as I haue done, my Lords page here a poor folower of mine.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Hei ho, your page then sha'not be super intendent vpon me? he shall not be addicted? he shall not be incident? he shall not be incident? he shall not be incident, shall he?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.l: O sweet signior Iuniper.
Iuni Sbloud stand away princocks? do not aggrauate my ioy.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Nay good Maister. Onion.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Nay and he haue the heart to draw my bloud, let him come.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Ile slice you Onion, Ile slice you?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Ile cleaue you Iuniper.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Why hold, hold, hough? what do you meane?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p:
Let him come Ingle, stand by boy, his allebaster blad
cannot feare me.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Why heare you sweet signior, let not there be any contention, betweene my Maister & you, about me, if you want a page sir, I can helpe you to a proper stripling.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Canst thou? what parentage? what ancestry? what genealogy is he?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: A french boy sir.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Has he his French linguist? has he?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: I, sir.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Then transport him: her's a crusado for thee.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: You will not, imbecell my seruant with your beneuolence will you, hold boy their's a portmantu for thee.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Lord sir.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Do take it boy, its three pounds ten shill. a portmantu.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: I thanke your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.l: Sirrah Ningle: thou art a traueller, and I honour thee.
I prithee discourse? cherish thy muse? discourse?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Of what sir?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Of what thou wilt. Sbloud? hang sorrow?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Prithy Valentine assoile me one thing.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Tis pitty to soile you sir, your new apparell.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Masse thou saist true, aparel makes a man forget himself.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.p: Begin, find your tongue Ningle.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now will gull these ganders rarely:
Gentlemen hauing in my peregrination through Mesopotamia.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Speake legibly, this gam's gone, without the great mercy of God,
Heres a fine tragedy indeed. Thers a Keisars royall.
By Gods lid, nor King nor Keisar shall?

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.p: Where? where? Finio, where be they.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.p: Go to, ile be with you anon.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: O her's the page signior Iuniper:

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.p: What sayth monsier Onion, boy.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: What say you sir.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Tread out boy.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Take vp, you meane sir.

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.p: Tread out I say, so, I thanke you, is this the boy.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Aue mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Who gaue you that name.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Giue me de name, vat name:

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: He thought your name had been, we yong gentlemen, you must do more then his legges can do for him, beare with him sir.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Sirrah giue me instance of your carriage? youle serue my turne, will you?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: What? turne vpon the toe.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: O signior no.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Page will you follow me, ile giue you good exhibition.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: By gar, shal not alone follow you, but shal leade you to.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Plaguie boy, he sooths his humour? these french villaines ha pockie wits.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Here? disarme me? take my semitary.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: O rare, this would be a rare man, and he had a little trauell, Balthasar, Martino, put off your shooes, and bid him coble them.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Freinds, friends, but pardon me for fellows, no more in occupation, no more in corporation, tis so pardon me, the case is alterd, this is law, but ile stand to nothing.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Fat so me tinke.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Well then God saue the dukes Maiesty, is this any harme now? speake, is this any harme now.

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: No nor good neither, Sbloud?

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Do you laugh at me? do you laugh at me? do you laugh at me?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I sir, we do.

sp.speaker: Iunip.
sp.p: You do indeed?

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: I indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Iuni.
sp.p: Tis sufficient, Page carry my purse, dog me?

sp.speaker: Oni.
sp.p: Gentlemen leaue him not, you see in what case he is, he is not in aduersity, his purse is full of money, leaue him not?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay gentle Rachel?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Away? forbeare? vngentle Angelo,
Touch not my body, with those impious hands,
That like hot Irons seare my trembling heart,
And make it hisse, at your disloyalty.
Was this your drift? to vse Fernezes name?
Was he your fittest stale, ô wild dishonor!

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Stay noble sir?

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Sbloud how like a puppet do you talke now?
Dishonor? what dishonor? come, come, foole,
Nay then I see y'are peeuish, S'heart dishonor?
To haue you to a priest and marry you,
And put you in an honorable state.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: To marry me? ô heauen, can it be?
That men should liue with such vnfeeling soules,
Without or touch or conscience of religion,
Or that their warping appetites should spoile
Those honor'd formes, that the true seale of friendship
Had set vpon their faces.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Do you heare? what needs all this? say, will you haue me, or no?

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Il'e haue you gone, and leaue me, if you would.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Leaue you? I was accurst to bring you hither,
And make so faire an offer to a foole.
A pox vpon you, why should you be coy,
What good thing haue you in you to be proud of?
Are y'any other then a beggars daughter?
Because you haue beauty. O Gods light a blast.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: You scornefull baggage, I lou'd thee not so much, but now I hate thee.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Vpon my knees, you heauenly powers, I thanke you,
That thus haue tam'd his wild affections.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: This will not do, I must to her againe,
Rachel, ô that thou sawst my heart, or didst behold,
The place from whence that scalding sigh euented.
Rachel, by Iesu I loue thee as my soule, Rachel, sweet Rachel.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: What againe returnd vnto this violent passion.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Do but heare me, by heauen I loue you Rachel.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Pray forbeare, ô that my Lord Ferneze were but here.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: Sbloud and he were, what would he do.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: This would he do base villaine.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: My deere Lord,

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: Thou monster, euen the soule of trechery!
O what dishonord title of reproch,
May my tongue spit in thy deserued face?
Me thinkes my very presence should inuert,
The steeled organs of those traytrous eyes,
To take into thy heart, and pierce it through:
Turn'st thou them on the ground? wretch, dig a graue,
With their sharp points, to hide th'abhorred head;
Sweet loue, thy wrongs haue beene too violent
Since my departure from thee, I perceiue:
But now true comfort shall againe appeare,
And like an armed angell guard thee safe
From all th'assaults of couered villany.
Come Mounsieur, let's go, & leaue this wretch to his despaire.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: My noble Ferneze.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: What canst thou speake to me, and not thy tongue,
Forc't with the torment of thy guilty soule
Breake that infected circle of thy mouth,
Like the rude clapper of a crazed bell.
I, that in thy bosome lodg'd my soule,
With all her traine of secrets, thinking them
To be as safe, and richly entertained,
As in a Princes court, or tower of strength,
And thou to proue a traitor to my trust,
And basely to expose it, ô this world!

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: My honorable Lord.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.l: The very owle, whom other birds do stare & wonder at,
Shall hoot at thee, and snakes in euery bush
Shall deafe thine eares with their—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Nay good my Lord, giue end vnto your passions.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.p: You shall see, I will redeeme your lost opinion.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: My Lord beleeue him.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Come, be satisfied, sweet Lord you know our haste,
Let vs to horse, the time for my engaged returne is past;
Be friends againe, take him along with you.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Come signior Angelo, hereafter proue more true.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Tut Maximillian, for your honor'd selfe,
I am perswaded, but no words shall turne
The edge of purposd vengeance on that wretch,
Come, bring him forth to execution.
Ile hang him for my sonne, he shall not scape,
Had he an hundred liues: Tell me vile slaue,
Thinkest thou I loue my sonne? is he my flesh?
Is he my bloud, my life? and shall all these be torturd for thy
sake, and not reueng'd? trusse vp the villaine.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: My Lord, there is no law to confirme this action.
Tis dishonorable.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Dishonorable? Maximilian?
It is dishonorable in Chamount, the day of his prefixt returne is past, and he shall pay fort.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord,
Vse your extreamest vengeance, ile be glad
To suffer ten times more, for such a friend.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O resolute and peremptory wretch!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My honored Lord, let vs intreat a word.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Ile heare no more, I say he shall not liue,
My selfe will do it. Stay, what forme is this
Stands betwixt him and me, and holds my hand.
What miracle is this? tis my owne fancy,
Carues this impression in me, my soft nature,
That euer hath retaind such foolish pitty,
Of the most abiect creatures misery,
That it abhorres it, what a child am I
To haue a child? Ay me, my son, my son.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: O my deere loue, what is become of thee?
What vniust absence layest thou on my brest,
Like waights of lead, when swords are at my backe,
That run me through with thy vnkind flight,
My gentle disposition waxeth wild,
I shall run frantike, ô my loue, my loue.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: My gold, my gold, my life, my soule, my heauen,
What is become of thee? see, ile impart
My miserable losse to my good Lord,
Let me haue search my Lord, my gold is gone.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: My sonne, Christophero, thinkst it possible,
I euer shall behold his face againe.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: O father wher's my loue, were you so carelesse
To let an vnthrift steale away your child.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I know your Lordship may find out my gold,
For Gods sake pitty me, iustice, sweet Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Now they haue yong Chamount? Christophero?
Surely they neuer will restore my sonne.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Who would haue thought you could haue beene so carelesse to loose your onely daughter.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Who would thinke,
That looking to my gold with such hares eyes,
That euer open, I euen when thy sleepe,
I thus should loose my gold, my noble Lord, what saies your
Lordship?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O my sonne, my sonne.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: My deerest Rachel?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: My most hony gold.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Heare me Christophero.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Nay heare me Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Heare me most honor'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: What rule is here?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O God that we should let Chamount escape.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: I and that Rachel, such a vertuous mayd, should be thus stolne away.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: And that my gold, being so hid in earth, should bee found out.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: O confusion of languages, & yet no tower of Babel!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ladies, beshrew me, if you come not fit to make a iangling consort, will you laugh to see three constant passions.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Stand by, I will vrge them, sweet Count, will you be comforted.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: It cannot be but he is handled the most cruelly,
That euer any noble prisoner was.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Steward, go cheere my Lord:

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Well, if Rachel tooke her flight willingly?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Sirrah, speake you touching your daughters flight?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O that I could so soone forget to know the thiefe againe, that had my gold, my gold.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Is not this pure?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O thou base wretch, ile drag thee through the streets.
sp.stage: Enter Balthasar, and whispers with him.
sp.l: And as a monster, make thee wondred at, how now.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Sweet Gentleman? how too vnworthily
Art thou thus tortured, braue Maximillian,
Pitty the poore youth and appease my father,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: How, my sonne returnd? O Maximillian,
Francisco, daughters? bid him enter here.
Dost thou not mocke me? O my deere Paulo welcome.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: My Lord Chamount?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My Gasper.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Rachel.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: My gold Rachel? my gold?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Some body bid the begger cease his noise.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: O signior Angelo, would you deceiue
Your honest friend, that simply trusted you?
Well Rachel: I am glad tho' art here againe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I faith she is not for you steward.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I beseech you maddam vrge your father.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I will anon? good Iaques be content.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Now God a mercy fortune, and sweet Venus,
Let Cupid do his part, and all is well.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Me thinks my heart's in heauen with this comfort.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Is this the true Italian courtesie.
Ferneze were you torturd thus in France? by my soules safety.

sp.speaker: Count:
sp.p: My most noble Lord? I do beseech your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Honored Count, wrong not your age with flexure of a knee,
I do impute it to those cares and griefes,
That did torment you in your absent sonne.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O worthy gentlemen, I am shamd
That my extreame affection to my sonne,
Should giue my honour so vncur'd a maine,
But my first sonne, being in Vicenza lost.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: How in Vicenza? lost you a sonne there?
About what time my Lord?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O the same night, wherein your noble father tooke the towne.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How long's that since my Lord? can you remember.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Tis now well nie vpon the twentith yeare.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: And how old was he then?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I cannot tel, betweene the yeares of three and soure, I take it.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Had he no speciall note in his attire,
Or otherwise, that you can call to mind.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: I cannot well remember his attire,
But I haue often heard his mother say:
He had about his necke a tablet,
Giuen to him by the Emperour Sigismund.
His Godfather, with this inscription,
Vnder the figure of a siluer Globe: En minimo, mundus.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How did you call your sonne my Lord?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Camillo Lord Chamount.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: Then no more my Gasper? but Camillo,
Take notice of your father, gentlemen:
Stand not amazd? here is a tablet,
With that inscription? found about his necke
That night, and in Vicenza by my father,
(Who being ignorant, what name he had)
Christned him Gasper, nor did I reueale,
This secret till this hower to any man.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O happy reuelation? ô blest hower? ô my Camillo.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: O strange my brother.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Maximilion? behold how the aboundance of his ioy Drownds him in teares of gladnesse.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: O my boy? forgiue thy fathers late austerity:

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: My Lord? I deliuered as much before, but your honour would not be perswaded, I will heareafter giue more obseruance to my visions? I drempt of this.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I can be still no longer, my good Lord,
Do a poore man some grace mongst all your ioyes.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why whats the matter Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I am robd, I am vndone my Lord, robd and vndone:
A heape of thirty thousand golden crownes,
Stolne from me in one minute, and I feare:
By her confedracy, that cals me father,
But she's none of mine, therefore sweet Lord:
Let her be tortured to confesse the truth.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: More wonders yet.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: How Iaques is not Rachel then thy daughter.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: No, I disclaime in her, I spit at her,
